claim: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of vomiting, abdominal pain, and constipation for the past 2 days. She has urinated frequently over the past week and has become excessively thirsty during this time. She has no significant past medical history. She is a 30-pack-year smoker. She appears confused. Her blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). She has dry oral mucosa. Lung auscultation shows rhonchi and wheezing localized to the right middle lobe area. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a shortened QT interval. A computed tomography scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s recent condition? : Adenocarcinoma

supporting.text: The patient's symptoms (vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria, polydipsia, confusion, dry mucous membranes, and hypotension) are consistent with hypercalcemia, which is commonly caused by malignancy such as adenocarcinoma.

attacks.text: The patient's symptoms (vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria, polydipsia, confusion, dry mucous membranes, and hypotension) are consistent with hypercalcemia, which is commonly caused by malignancy such as adenocarcinoma.
Hypercalcemia can also be caused by primary hyperparathyroidism, which is more common in elderly women and does not necessarily indicate malignancy.

The patient's smoking history and localized lung findings (rhonchi and wheezing) could suggest a pulmonary infection or COPD exacerbation, which may also contribute to her symptoms independently of malignancy.
Primary hyperparathyroidism typically presents with a longer history of mild symptoms and is less likely to cause acute severe hypercalcemia with such pronounced symptoms as seen in this patient.
While pulmonary infection or COPD could explain some symptoms, they do not account for the shortened QT interval on ECG, which is a hallmark of hypercalcemia.
Primary hyperparathyroidism can occasionally present with acute severe hypercalcemia, especially in cases of parathyroid crisis, which should not be ruled out without checking PTH levels.
